required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Does Meal Replacement With a Carbohydrates and Protein Supplement Induce Weight Loss in Overweight and/or Obese Adults?
clinical_study.official_title: Does Meal Replacement With a Carbohydrates and Protein Supplement Induce Weight Loss in Overweight and/or Obese Adults?

brief_summary.textblock: Participants will be randomized into two groups, one group will be the control (no intervention at all) and the other will be CHO-PRO (meal replacement, Generation UCAN supplement, 400ml, 20% solution). Prior to the start of the experiment, all participants will be asked to record their satiety ratings, appetite and desire to eat (10-point visual analogue scale) 30, 60 and 120 minutes after their regular dinner for 3 days. On the first day of the experiment, all participants will be asked to measure their waist and hip circumferences, fasting blood glucose level, maximal number of pushups and body weight using a scale at home prior to breakfast. Instructions on how to do the measurements properly will be recorded in a video and distributed to the participants. Participants in the control group will not receive any intervention. Participants in the CHO-PRO group will be provided with the supplement and they will be asked to consume the CHO - protein supplement (Generation UCAN supplement, 250ml, 10% solution) 6 to 7 hours after lunch, in place of their dinner for 6 weeks. They will also be asked to record their satiety ratings, appetite and desire to eat (10-point visual analogue scale) 30, 60 and 120 minutes after each meal replacement drink. All participants will be required to complete a dietary record, prior to, and during (at weeks 2 and 4) intervention. To track adherence of the CHO-PRO group, participants will be asked to check off the calendar that they did not consume the meal replacement due to various reasons. On day 43, all participants will be asked measure again waist and hip circumferences, fasting blood glucose level, maximal number of pushups and body weight using a scale at home prior to breakfast again.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day prior to the start of the experiment and on the 31st day of the experiment
primary_outcome.description: body weight will be measured using a scale at home prior to breakfast

secondary_outcome.measure: changes in waist and hip circumferences
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day prior to the start of the experiment and on the 31st day of the experiment
secondary_outcome.description: waist and hip circumferences will be measured using a measuring tape at home prior to breakfast

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day prior to the start of the experiment and on the 31st day of the experiment
secondary_outcome.description: blood glucose will be measured through finger pricks

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30, 60 and 120 minutes after each meal replacement drink
secondary_outcome.description: appetite ratings will be asked with the use a 10 point visual analog scale (VAS), 10 being strong desire to consume food and 1 being no desire to consume food at all

secondary_outcome.measure: changes in desire to eat ratings
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30, 60 and 120 minutes after each meal replacement drink
secondary_outcome.description: desire to eat ratings will be asked with the use a 10 point visual analog scale (VAS), 10 being no desire to eat at all and 1 being strong desire to eat

arm_group.description: no supplement will be provided on the day of the experiment

intervention.description: satiety ratings, appetite and desire to eat (10-point visual analogue scale) will be measured at 30, 60 and 120 minutes after each meal replacement drink
meal replacement, Generation UCAN supplement, 400ml, 20% solution

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- sedentary (<2 moderate exercise bouts/wk)
- between the ages of 18 to 50y
- body mass index (BMI) between 18-30
Exclusion Criteria:
- do not eat three meals a day typically
- taking medication that affects their eating patterns
- have metabolic and gastrointestinal diseases
